section_title: Variables and Data Types in Python
section_description: Variables and data types are fundamental building blocks in Python programming. This section introduces how to create and use variables to store data, and explores Python's built-in data types. Understanding these concepts is essential for writing effective Python programs.
learning_objectives: Define what variables are and how they are used in Python
Identify and use Python's basic data types (integers, floats, strings, booleans)
Create and manipulate variables in Python programs
Apply type conversion techniques to change data types when needed
Use appropriate data types to solve simple programming problems

lessons.lesson_objective: Understand what variables are and how to create and use them in Python

exercises.exercise_instructions: Create three variables: one for your name (string), one for your age (integer), and one for your favorite color (string). Print each variable with a descriptive label.
Create two variables with numeric values. Perform addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division operations with these variables. Store each result in a new variable and print all results.

Identify which of the following variable names are valid in Python: 'my_var', '2ndPlace', 'favorite-color', 'class', '_private', 'firstName', 'lastName$'. For each invalid name, explain why it's invalid and suggest a valid alternative.

lessons.lesson_objective: Identify and use Python's numeric data types (integers and floats) in programs

exercises.exercise_instructions: Create variables for two integers and two floating-point numbers. Perform all basic arithmetic operations (+, -, *, /, //, %, **) on each pair. Print the results with descriptive labels indicating the operation performed.

Create a program that demonstrates the difference between integer division (//) and float division (/). Show how to convert between int and float types using int() and float() functions. Create at least 5 examples showing different conversion scenarios.

Write Python expressions to calculate the following: 1) Area of a rectangle, 2) Circumference of a circle, 3) Simple interest, 4) Fahrenheit to Celsius conversion. Use appropriate variables and print the results with appropriate formatting.

lessons.lesson_objective: Understand and manipulate string data in Python

exercises.exercise_instructions: Create strings using single quotes, double quotes, and triple quotes. For each string type, demonstrate when it's most appropriate to use. Include examples with quotes inside strings and multi-line strings.

Create a string with at least 10 words. Use at least 5 different string methods (like .upper(), .lower(), .title(), .replace(), .split()) to manipulate this string. Print each result with a description of what method was used.

Create a string with a sentence. Use slicing to extract: 1) The first word, 2) The last word, 3) Every other character, 4) The string in reverse, 5) A substring from the middle. Print each result with a description of what was extracted.

lessons.lesson_title: Boolean Data Type and Type Conversion
lessons.lesson_objective: Use boolean values and convert between different data types in Python

exercises.exercise_instructions: Create 10 different expressions that evaluate to boolean values. Include comparison operators (==, !=, >, <, >=, <=) and logical operators (and, or, not). Print each expression and its result.

Create variables of different data types (string, integer, float, boolean). Convert each variable to all other types using appropriate conversion functions (str(), int(), float(), bool()). Print each conversion, noting which conversions are possible and which cause errors.

Write a program that takes user input as a string, converts it to different types, and performs operations appropriate to each type. For example, if the input represents a number, perform arithmetic; if it's text, manipulate the string; if it's 'True' or 'False', use it as a boolean.
